module.name: flavor
module.title: Flavor: Dissolved Molecules, Chemical Assessment of Food
module.description: Flavor is dissolved molecules detected by taste receptors. Five basic tastes: sweet, salty, sour, bitter, umami. Gustatory sense. Immediate chemical evaluation.

essence.geometric: Flavor = 0D-1D. Point contact (molecule on receptor) → temporal sequence (chewing, swallowing).
essence.physical: Water-soluble or fat-soluble molecules contacting taste receptors on tongue.
essence.experiential: Taste. Sweet, salty, sour, bitter, umami. Pleasure, disgust, evaluation.
essence.consciousness: Taste's object. Immediate judgment: nutritious or toxic? Safe to swallow?
essence.survival: Most ancient evaluative sense. Life-or-death decision in real-time.

sweet.molecules: Sugars (glucose, fructose, sucrose), some amino acids, artificial sweeteners

salty.molecules: Primarily sodium chloride (NaCl), some other salts
salty.receptor: ENaC (epithelial sodium channel) - ion channel, not GPCR
salty.hedonic: Pleasant in moderation, unpleasant at high concentration
salty.examples: Table salt, seawater, cured meats, chips

sour.molecules: Acids (H+ ions) - acetic, citric, malic, lactic acids
sour.evolutionary: Warning of potential toxicity or unripeness
sour.hedonic: Aversive at high intensity, can be pleasant at low (lemonade)

bitter.molecules: Alkaloids, toxins (quinine, caffeine, many plant compounds)
bitter.receptor: T2R family (~25 different receptors in humans)
bitter.evolutionary: Strong poison detection - most sensitive taste
bitter.hedonic: Innately aversive (learned to tolerate: coffee, beer, vegetables)
bitter.examples: Coffee, dark chocolate, grapefruit, Brussels sprouts
bitter.variation: High genetic variation (some people very sensitive, others not)

umami.discovery: Kikunae Ikeda (1908), recognized as 5th taste late 20th century
umami.examples: Parmesan cheese, tomatoes, soy sauce, MSG, meat broth

calcium.status: Some evidence in animals, unclear in humans

kokumi.definition: Not a taste but taste enhancer

taste_perception.location: Taste buds on tongue, palate, throat

papillae.fungiform: Mushroom-shaped, front 2/3 of tongue, 1-15 buds each
papillae.foliate: Folds on sides of tongue, many buds
papillae.circumvallate: Large, back of tongue in V-shape, ~250 buds each (~12 total)
papillae.filiform: Most numerous, no taste buds (texture detection only)

types.type_III: Detect sour (ion channels), synapses with nerves

taste_receptor_cells.no_axons: Not neurons, release ATP to signal nerves

taste_map_myth.myth: Different tongue regions for different tastes
taste_map_myth.truth: All areas detect all tastes (though small sensitivity differences)
taste_map_myth.fact: Entire tongue sensitive to all basic tastes

taste.definition: Five basic tastes detected by tongue

flavor.definition: Multimodal experience: taste + smell + texture + temperature + pain

retronasal_olfaction.definition: Smell of food in mouth reaching nose from behind
retronasal_olfaction.importance: Most of what we call 'taste' is actually smell
retronasal_olfaction.test: Hold nose while eating - flavor becomes bland, only basic tastes remain

chemesthesis.definition: Chemical senses detected by trigeminal nerve (not taste)
chemesthesis.not_taste: These are pain/temperature/touch sensations, not gustatory

supertasters.sensitivity: Higher sensitivity to bitter, sweet, fat
supertasters.gene: Often have two copies of PAV variant of TAS2R38

non_tasters.gene: Often have two copies of AVI variant of TAS2R38

PROP_PTC.taste: Extremely bitter to some, tasteless to others

innate.sweet: Universally liked from birth (breast milk is sweet)

age_changes.children: Strong preference for sweet, rejection of bitter
age_changes.elderly: Taste sensitivity declines, may prefer stronger flavors

ageusia.causes: Nerve damage, head trauma, medications, radiation

taste_enhancement.umami: Enhances savory, reduces need for salt

maillard_reaction.definition: Browning reaction between amino acids and sugars
maillard_reaction.result: Hundreds of flavor compounds (roasted, toasted, meaty)
maillard_reaction.examples: Seared meat, toasted bread, coffee roasting

mineral_balance.salty: Sodium essential for nerves, muscles, fluid balance

immediate_evaluation.decision: Swallow or spit? Safe or dangerous?

cfo_integration.reason: Taste = point contact (molecule-receptor) → temporal sequence (chewing, swallowing)

applications.nutrition: Understanding food preferences, encouraging healthy eating

taste_qualia.question: Why does sweet taste like sweet?
taste_qualia.ineffability: Cannot describe taste to someone who never tasted it

individual_differences.question: Do we all taste the same thing?

acquired_tastes.question: How do we learn to like initially aversive tastes?
acquired_tastes.plasticity: Taste system more flexible than thought

external.citation: Chandrashekar, J., et al. (2006). The receptors and cells for mammalian taste
Breslin, P. A. (2013). An Evolutionary Perspective on Food and Human Taste

meta.experience: Five basic tastes: sweet, salty, sour, bitter, umami
